MetaText.name: summary
MetaText.TextSeg: 199 10012 3.5 4.5 B, D, F, V at Broadway-Lafayette St.; 6 at Astor Pl.
includes a shelling demonstration from your server) is the true

Meta.name: fieldAttributes
Meta.MetaString: B, D, F, V at Broadway-Lafayette St.; 6 at Astor Pl.

Meta.name: fieldAttributes
Meta.MetaString: 54 Great Jones St, New York, NY 10012, USA

Meta.name: fieldAttributes
Meta.MetaString: you won’t believe you’re still in noho when you step into this lively little roadhouse with the blasting jukebox. you’ll likely wait for a table, but you won’t wait for a menu, since the specials are printed on a blackboard and change daily. creole favorites like blackened catfish, gumbo and assorted po-boy sandwiches will sate your hankering for the bayou, but the spicy and fragrant crawfish boil (which includes a shelling demonstration from your server) is the true test for cajun mavens. be sure to order the fresh, honey-topped jalapeno corn bread and red-hot bloody marys with everything.

Meta.name: fieldAttributes
Meta.MetaString: It's so sad to see one of my favorites joints going down hill. The brunch has been inconsistent lately. I ordered the Crescent City which comes with biscuits and they were as hard as hockey pucks. The Cajun food is about as far as you can get from authentic. It's as if the cooks have never heard of Cajun cuisine. The gumbo was as thick as molasses and way too rich. That was the good part of the meal. The blackened catfish was by far the worst I've ever had. It lacked seasoning of any kind. The fish had no flavor whatsoever. I asked for remoulade sauce, which they did not have, and settled for equally bland sauce that didn't help. Overall, I'm just disappointed that the owners would serve food of such low quality. It's the lack of attention to details that is the problem here. Let's get hands-on and get this place back to what it once was.

MetaText.name: summary
MetaText.TextSeg: if you just want to taste-
, you can easily construct a meal out of any of the two dozen appetizers.

Meta.name: fieldAttributes
Meta.MetaString: a friendly mix of neighborhood regulars flocks to this fine-tuned eatery with reliable vietnamese food. unlike the barebones eat-and-run feel of so many other places, vermicelli has velvet curtains, maroon cushions, and muted lighting that makes everyone look rested. you can take your time here. the curry, lemongrass, sesame, basil, peanuts, mint, sugar cane, and chilies characteristic of vietnamese cooking make their appearance in traditional dishes like cháo tôm, sugarcane sticks encircled with grilled shrimp, and in marinated beef and chicken dishes. count on its high-quality, tender meat, and delicate sauces that don't upstage the meat. on the menu are an array of saigon rice noodle soups and the namesake thin rice noodlesx97a staple of vietnamese cooking. skip the starchy banh hoi, warm noodles paired with spring rolls, shrimp, and chicken skewers; it lacks a sauce to blend the starch and protein, and the noodles cool quickly. tangy, ginger-infused saigon chicken had plenty of kick, as did bo la nho, grape leaves stuffed with delicious barbequed ground beef and peanuts. if you just want to taste-test, you can easily construct a meal out of any of the two dozen appetizers.

Meta.name: fieldAttributes
Meta.MetaString: My son has been telling me for years that this is his favorite restaurant in NYC. and last night my husband and myself joined him there for dinner. Three of the dishes were outstanding. The lobster, shanghi chicken and the beer battered shrimp were perfect. We were a little disappointed in the whole shrimp with ginger. The service was very good. We look forward to going back again and this time we will try the pork chops that we have heard are delicious. It was worth the trip from Rockland County to drive to this gem of a restaurant.

MetaText.name: summary
MetaText.TextSeg: the roast half-chickenx97what some would argue is the litmus

Meta.name: fieldAttributes
Meta.MetaString: french bistros in this town can feel like disney world, referencing the idea of paris and its informal cafés but failing to capture the city’s discreet charms. williamsburg’s juliette, however, resists the temptation to take french accents too far, instead offering a restaurant with just a touch of amelie whimsy. the large space comprises a bar area with floor-to-ceiling glass windows, a banquette-lined back room, a glass-ceilinged indoor patio, and a large roof garden with its own bar. throughout is a romantic mix of french country, deco, and art nouveaux97warmly lit by antique light fixtures. the menu is equally classic, with an assortment of salads followed by favorites like moules, steak frites, and a niçoise salad. the french onion soup is surprisingly sweet, with a stronger beef-bullion flavor than one might expect, but the cambraix yellow-and-red-beet salad is beautifully dressed with a light vinaigrette and touch of horseradish cream. steak dishes rely on their sauces (bordelaise or peppercorn) but lack a beefy or char-grilled flavor on their own. the roast half-chickenx97what some would argue is the litmus test of any bistrox97is a winner, the skin crunchy and slightly caramelized, the meat tender and juicy.

Meta.name: fieldAttributes
Meta.MetaString: Been to Juliette three times and loved it all three. The food there is great. Steak tartar was excellent as were most of the appetizers (french onion soup, potato pancakes, & stuffed mussels special were standouts). I would actually say the appetizers are their strength over the main courses. The Salmon main course was stand-out for me and the Juliette burger was pretty delicious as well. Tried the grilled chicken sandwich which was so-so. The pommes frites, though good, are by no means remarkable nor the anywhere near the quality of other ones I've had at NYC French restaurants. Had the cassoule (sp?) special the first night I was there, which was outstanding and I would highly recommend it if it returns to the menu. The most remarkable thing I found about the restaurant though was the great service. Servers on the Bedford Ave area always seem to have severe attitude and act like they merely deign to work when they're not pursuing their art. Not the case at Juliette, servers were very friendly and attentive all three times. The maitre'd was particularly nice and moved us from our table after we complained about the cold air drafting in from the outside. Decor is pretty typical for a French bistro. In terms of price, it's definitely not cheap Brooklyn dining, but I felt it was very good value for the quality of the food.

MetaText.name: summary
MetaText.TextSeg: of time for over 30 years like tombolino restaurant.
most of all, the restaurant has kept diners returning over & over

Meta.name: fieldAttributes
Meta.MetaString: in the world of restaurants, where trendy spots are opening everyday, it’s nice to find a restaurant that has withstood the test of time for over 30 years like tombolino restaurant. most of all, the restaurant has kept diners returning over & over for the last three decades. it is up – held by executive chef & owner pietro siciliano, with the help of his sons. their excitement & energy for what they do & eagerness to improve with every diner they serve is nothing short of incredible. all this has not gone unnoticed the zagat’s rates the restaurant as excellent, applauding tombolino for its delicious cuisine & calling it the site of wonderful dining experiences. tombolino is a recipient of the wine spectator magazine award of excellence, since 2005. the restaurant proudly displays more then 500 bottles of wine mostly from italy, california, & france. if you wander in you can enjoy the daily specials in any of the two charming dinning rooms or take a look at the wine cellar.

Meta.name: fieldAttributes
Meta.MetaString: Banquet/Private RoomsFireplaceFull BarNon-Smoking RestaurantPersonal wines welcome (corkage fee applies)Private RoomTakeoutWheelchair AccessWine

MetaText.name: summary
MetaText.TextSeg: feel-good food and drink." along with
tubes filled with herbal nourishments from flax to echinacea decorating

Meta.name: fieldAttributes
Meta.MetaString: 523 Hudson St, New York, NY 10014, USA

Meta.name: fieldAttributes
Meta.MetaString: the doctor is in at this hip and healthy chain of "feel-good food and drink." along with test tubes filled with herbal nourishments from flax to echinacea decorating the walls, there's a symptom chart with ready-to-be-made, drinkable remedies. prone to anxiety attacks? try the blues blaster, a banana, apple cider, strawberry, and blueberry blend with a st. john's wort booster. or sip a skinnyx97banana, rice milk, peaches, melon, lecithin and "slim" protein mixx97to beat cellulite. comfy green and purple cushions offer relaxed seating for enjoying the smoothies, which are always thick, creamy, fresh, and fruity, whether you create your own or choose from the list of suggested concoctions. but the menu holds more than blended beverages, so don't overlook other wholesome items like the garlicky hummus wrap or the sesame, edamame, seaweed, and shredded carrot salad. everything is guaranteed to be completely natural, preservative-free, and without refined sugar or saturated fat. you can also pick up protein blends and herbal tinctures at each store to replicate the shakes at home. still, it's worth visiting the spot for the wellness vibe alone, which is so sincere you half expect the staff to ask: "you want a side of therapy with that shake?"

MetaText.name: summary
MetaText.TextSeg: com/ 212-410-4300 if the jam-packed sfoglia , up the street is any
, the yogurtlu kebab, was suitably rich and delicious,

Meta.name: fieldAttributes
Meta.MetaString: 1361 Lexington Ave, New York, NY 10128, USA

Meta.name: fieldAttributes
Meta.MetaString: if the jam-packed sfoglia , up the street is any indication, denizens of carnegie hill are desperate for good food and cozy surroundings. peri ela delivers on both accounts, with its snug, wood-paneled, tin-ceilinged space filling up each night with locals tucking into platters of turkish meze and kebabs. owners silay and jill ciner named the spot after their two daughters and have installed an all-turkish kitchen crew. with only 35 seats and a bar, the onetime diner does get crowded, and so do the tables, especially when littered with multiple meze (creamy cacik, tangy bean salads, springy grape leaves, and several worthy eggplant variations) and a kebab or two. our go-to turkish litmus test, the yogurtlu kebab, was suitably rich and delicious, if portioned more for delicate manhattan appetites than robust gravesend ones, its succulent slices of well-done lamb arrayed over pita croutons drenched with thick, garlicky yogurt and tomato sauce. a very welcome addition, and let's hope the beginnings of a new restaurant row.

Meta.name: fieldAttributes
Meta.MetaString: We came here in a snowstorm. My friend had been waiting at the bar for 20 minutes and there were three empty tables (large ones). I'd been trying to call them for the last hour or two but only an answering machine. The hostess asked if we wanted a table and we said yes, of course, since the bar stools were rickety and uncomfortable (though the place was intimate and had a good atmosphere). Well, I'm sorry, there'll be a twenty minute wait. Hmmm. It's a snow storm, we're in the East 90s which is a deserted neighborhood. Does she think it's Cipriani's or something? When I complained to the manager he wasn't helpful at all. This doesn't seem like a place with a sense of the neighborhood or their customers. They implied we'd be seated but then tried to give us attitude. Kind of reminded me of the days they wouldn't let me into Studio 54. Needless to say, we won't be back. There aren't too many places in the East 90s worth eating at, but I'd rather cook at home than have this kind of snobbery.

MetaText.name: summary
MetaText.TextSeg: com/ 212-932-0068 if there’s hope for the beleaguered new york diner, it may rest on the shoulders
this one, decorated in cheery deco shades of pink,

Meta.name: fieldAttributes
Meta.MetaString: if there’s hope for the beleaguered new york diner, it may rest on the shoulders of frank tsiamtsouris and fotis hilas, the brothers-in-law behind key west and four similarly shiny manhattan spots (metro, city, and manhattan diners uptown, good stuff downtown). this one, decorated in cheery deco shades of pink, peach, and turquoise, proves the success of their formula: give a healthy, global spin to a classic diner menu, hire servers who could probably juggle torches while serving coffee, and keep the rooms clean, bright, and inviting. such standards have kept key west perpetually packed since its doors opened in 1987, and regulars get indulged by servers who’ve been here almost as long. massive burgers, omelettes, and salads are the best options; soups, fish dishes, and greek plates get surprisingly skillful treatment, but limp pastas and stir-fries do not. dense cheesecake makes a satisfying finish, and coffeex97the true test of any dinerx97arrives hot and strong.

Meta.name: fieldAttributes
Meta.MetaString: yummy pancakes. nice thick cut steak fries, and a dessert menu that'll knock your socks off. I saw the guy behind the counter making delish looking coke floats.rnrnnice basic diner for nice basic diner food.

MetaText.name: summary
MetaText.TextSeg: 30 11354 E, F, G, R, V at Jackson Heights-Roosevelt Ave.;
dishes for malaysian restaurants; sentosa’s are smashing.

Meta.name: fieldAttributes
Meta.MetaString: E, F, G, R, V at Jackson Heights-Roosevelt Ave.; 7 at Flushing-Main St.

Meta.name: fieldAttributes
Meta.MetaString: good restaurants don’t die. they just move to this flushing side street, where the relocated sentosa, a top-notch malaysian kitchen late of manhattan’s chinatown, has materialized two doors down from the transplanted spicy & tasty. like its szechuan neighbor, sentosa has spruced up its décor but preserved its brash, taste bud-grabbing flavors characteristic of its native cuisine. malaysian is the ultimate fusion food, with a penchant for the pungent shrimp paste called belacan and a tendency to bury treasures, like shrimp and squid stuffed inside tofu. roti canai, the fried pancake you dip into chicken curry, and beef rendang simmered in a chili powdered coconut milk curry are our go-to litmus test dishes for malaysian restaurants; sentosa’s are smashing. so is its ice kanang abc, a southeast asian kitchen sink of a shaved-ice concoction, full of red beans, corn kernels, palm seeds, and jelly.

MetaText.name: title
MetaText.TextSeg: How you fix a mistake is the big

MetaText.name: summary
MetaText.TextSeg: We've become regulars at Hearth, and love it.
Saturday found the restaurant NOT in good form.
How you fix it is the

Meta.name: fieldAttributes
Meta.MetaString: We've become regulars at Hearth, and love it. Saturday found the restaurant NOT in good form. We sat down, ordered our meal, and half an hour later, our appetizers had not arrived. It was odd because, fifteen minutes before, the waiter had come by to tell us they were on the way, and he was sorry for the delay. Ten minutes later, we heard the chef yell WHERE ARE THOSE FIRSTS? Talking about ours. We were ready to leave, because that wasn't the only problem. Then they came out, and the manager came out, with corporate double speak, just making us angrier. Finally, the chef came out, serving us our entrees personally, and apologizing for the miscommunication. rnrnWhat miscommunication? There wasn't any, at least not on our part. The food WAS good, and we enjoyed it and ordered dessert, which was also wonderful. rnrnWhen we asked for the bill, they told us they were comping us on the whole dinner because of their goofs. Could NOT have been more apologetic. We didn't feel we could accept that, and suggested instead that they buy us our drinks. Again, you couldn't have seen more appreciative people. rnrnRestaurants make mistakes. They ALL do. Sometimes they happen to good customers. It's going to happen. How you fix it is the test of a good restaurant. Hearth is a VERY good restaurant.

Meta.name: fieldAttributes
Meta.MetaString: How you fix a mistake is the big test.

MetaText.name: summary
MetaText.TextSeg: After reading the many reviews and the cookbook rnI finally got the chance to
Not only was out waiter and his staff attentive, but friendly,

Meta.name: fieldAttributes
Meta.MetaString: After reading the many reviews and the cookbook rnI finally got the chance to test it out. My lunch was far more plesant than imagined- from food to service- everything was perfect to the corners of the table. Not only was out waiter and his staff attentive, but friendly, personable, and informative. The three courses I had were all a different dance on the tastebuds- every morsel was clean and fresh, and soothing. Portions were just right and the presentation was immpecable. rnI don't know Marcus- but have seen him on interviews and such- and seems like a laidback person with a lot of finesse, and thats very much reflected in his establishment
